text.headline: Overview
text.text:
This project serves to document buildings and businesses the occupied the space that is now the Jefferson National Expansion Memorial, better known as the Gateway Arch.  To build the Gateway Arch, 37 city blocks of downtown St. Louis had to be cleared. This area was roughly the original confines of the village of St. Louis. Due to the area’s age, there were many historic buildings torn down. It may seem strange to some as to why the city of St. Louis would agree to let the National Park service destroy their historic city but there is important context surrounding the situation. Despite the Gateway Arch being built during the 1960s, planning for it began during the Great Depression in the 1930s. President Franklin Delano Roosevelt wanted to create a monument to Thomas Jefferson’s westward expansion. More importantly, building this monument would create jobs as part of his New Deal policies.

To accomplish the goal of building a monument, the federal government estimated that it would cost $30 million. The bill would be split: $7.5 million would come from the city of St. Louis and the remainder would come from the federal government. As a result, the city of St. Louis held a vote on a bond issue to raise the $7.5 million in 1935. The vote on the bond issue was an overwhelming 2.5 to 1 approval. (“River Front Bond Issue Approved”). The extremely high approval raised some concerns and there were calls to investigate the election for fraud but the Public Works Administration who carried out the election was never obligated to and chose not to investigate. (“PWA Denies Inquiry.”).

Despite the possible voter fraud, the project continued but quickly ran into other hurdles. Several landowners sued the federal government asking for more money in exchange for their land. This process took several years and was delayed even further by the United States’ involvement in World War II. Eventually the war ended, and the cases were settled allowing for the demolition of the 37 blocks to commence.

There is some speculation that the project was only meant to clear the “blighted” property on the riverfront and raise property values of surrounding land. Despite being less romantic than creating a monument to Thomas Jefferson’s Luisiana Purchase, clearing the land appears to have been successful. Much of downtown St. Louis surrounding the Arch comprises of large venues or office buildings; no longer are the streets lined with cast iron and brick facades.

text.headline: Valentine Warehouse Co.
text.text: The Valentine Warehouse Company was one of the businesses that sued the federal government for more land. Their primary business was storing food products including sugar from C&H Sugar Co. They were located along the river front and stressed that having direct access to barges on the river was very important for their business. (Ried)

text.headline: Mangelsdorf Seed Co.
text.text: The Mangelsdorf Seed Co. also known as Mangelsdorf & Bros. Inc. was a seven story wholesale seed company that also sued the federal government in the same case as the Valentine Warehouse Co. (Ried)

text.headline: Moser Paper Box Co.
text.text: The Moser Paper Box Co. was originally located within the confines of the Jefferson National Expansion Memorial Project at 200 Elm St. The company bought a new building from Langenberg Manufacturing Company at 4500 N. Euclid to replace their Elm St. location. (“Moser Box Company”)

text.headline: The Old Rock House
text.text: The Old Rock House was the oldest building in St. Louis at the time it was demolished being built in 1767. According to the St. Louis Post-Dispatch it was “used in succession as city hall, schoolhouse, fur storehouse, slave billet, tavern, jail, and café.” (“Typical Scenes”) The Old Rock House was one of the three buildings initially spared during the demolition of the riverfront--alongside the Old Cathedral and Old Courthouse. Originally the plan was to use the Old Rock House as the entrance to the Gateway Arch. However, in 1957 the National Park Service revised the arch grounds plan and relocated the riverfront railroad line to a tunnel that passed directly under the Old Rock House. When it was deconstructed, each stone from the building was numbered and stored. The National Park Service was going to reproduce the building somewhere else on the arch grounds, but the stones have since been lost. (Toft)

text.headline: Mednik Wiping Materials Co.
text.text: The Mednik Wiping Materials Co. was an industrial soap company that moved to a space on the corner of Eighth and Barry streets following the condemnation of their previous location at 115 Valentine Street. (“Mednik Company”) (“Genealogy”)

text.headline: Vacant Comercial Space
text.text: Not all buildings in the area were occupied. This is an example of a vacant space that many supporters of the Memorial pointed to when they claimed the area was unkept. (“7-15 North Main Street”)

text.headline: Blanton Co.
text.text: Blanton Co. produced oleomargarine at two buildings at 318 South Second St. (“Proposed River Front Memorial”)

text.headline: McKesson-Merrell Drug Co.
text.text: McKesson-Merrell Drug Co. was located across the street from the Old Court House where there is now green space leading towards the Gateway Arch. (“Proposed River Front Memorial”)

text.headline: The Old Cathedral
text.text: The Old Cathedral was another of the three buildings spared alongside the previously mentioned Old Rock House and the Old Courthouse. It is the fourth church to be built on that parcel of land that has had a church since the founding of St. Louis. (Basilica of St. Louis)

text.headline: Missouri Pacific Railroad Records
text.text: It was a six-story building located at the corner of First and Olive streets. (“Proposed River Front Memorial”)

text.headline: Bardenheier Building
text.text: The building was built in 1873 and was used as storage for wines and liquors. ((“Typical Scenes”)

text.headline: Prunty Seed Co.
text.text: The building that housed the Prunty Seed Co. originally was built as the Merchants’ Exchange building in 1874. ((“Typical Scenes”)

text.headline: Panama Building
text.text: The Panama Building was an upscale office building that was also a hotel for a brief period. The first Weather Bureau reports for St. Louis were recorded on the roof of the building. ((“Typical Scenes”)
